file.content:
OPEN This is open, and cannot be resolved with a finite computation.
Let $h(n)$ be minimal such that any group $G$ with the property that any subset of $>n$ elements contains some $x\neq y$ such that $xy=yx$ can be covered by at most $h(n)$ many Abelian subgroups.

Estimate $h(n)$ as well as possible.
#117: [Er90][Er97f][Va99,5.75]
group theory
Disclaimer: The open status of this problem reflects the current belief of the owner of this website. There may be literature on this problem that I am unaware of, which may partially or completely solve the stated problem. Please do your own literature search before expending significant effort on solving this problem. If you find any relevant literature not mentioned here, please add this in a comment.
Pyber [Py87] has proved there exist constants $c_2>c_1>1$ such that $c_1^n<h(n)<c_2^n$. Erdős [Er97f] writes that the lower bound was already known to Isaacs.

View the LaTeX source

This page was last edited 23 January 2026.

1→import Mathlib.Data.Complex.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Algebra.Polynomial.Basic
     3→import Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Measure.Hausdorff
     4→import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.Real
     5→
     6→open Polynomial MeasureTheory
     7→
     8→/-- The lemniscate interior of a complex polynomial p:
     9→    the open sublevel set {z ∈ ℂ : |p(z)| < 1}. -/
    10→def lemniscateInterior (p : Polynomial ℂ) : Set ℂ :=
    11→  {z : ℂ | Complex.abs (p.eval z) < 1}
    12→
    13→/-- The 2D area of a subset of ℂ, given by the 2-dimensional Hausdorff measure. -/
    14→noncomputable def area (S : Set ℂ) : ℝ≥0∞ :=
    15→  Measure.hausdorffMeasure 2 S
    16→
    17→/--
    18→Erdős–Herzog–Piranian Conjecture (Problem #116) [EHP58, Er61, Er82e, Er90, Er97c]:
    19→
    20→Let p(z) = ∏ᵢ (z - zᵢ) be a polynomial of degree n ≥ 1 with all roots zᵢ
    21→in the closed unit disk (|zᵢ| ≤ 1). Then the 2D Lebesgue measure (area) of
    22→the lemniscate interior {z ∈ ℂ : |p(z)| < 1} satisfies
    23→
    24→  |{z : |p(z)| < 1}| ≫ n^{-O(1)}.
    25→
    26→That is, there exist universal constants κ > 0 and δ > 0 such that for all n ≥ 1
    27→and all such polynomials, the area is at least δ · n^{-κ}.
    28→
    29→The lower bound ≫ n^{-4} follows from a result of Pommerenke [Po61].
    30→The stronger lower bound ≫ (log n)^{-1} was proved by Krishnapur, Lundberg,
    31→and Ramachandran [KLR25], which in particular settles this conjecture.
    32→
    33→Pólya [Po28] showed the area is always at most π, with equality only when all
    34→roots are equal.
    35→-/
    36→theorem erdos_problem_116 :
    37→    ∃ (κ δ : ℝ), 0 < δ ∧ 0 < κ ∧
    38→    ∀ (n : ℕ), 1 ≤ n →
    39→    ∀ (roots : Fin n → ℂ), (∀ i, Complex.abs (roots i) ≤ 1) →
    40→    ENNReal.ofReal (δ * (n : ℝ) ^ (-κ)) ≤
    41→      area (lemniscateInterior (∏ i : Fin n, (X - C (roots i)))) :=
    42→  sorry
    43→

file.content:
import Mathlib.Data.Complex.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.Polynomial.Basic
import Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Measure.Hausdorff
import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.Real

open Polynomial MeasureTheory

/-- The lemniscate interior of a complex polynomial p:
    the open sublevel set {z ∈ ℂ : |p(z)| < 1}. -/
def lemniscateInterior (p : Polynomial ℂ) : Set ℂ :=
  {z : ℂ | Complex.abs (p.eval z) < 1}

/-- The 2D area of a subset of ℂ, given by the 2-dimensional Hausdorff measure. -/
noncomputable def area (S : Set ℂ) : ℝ≥0∞ :=
  Measure.hausdorffMeasure 2 S

/--
Erdős–Herzog–Piranian Conjecture (Problem #116) [EHP58, Er61, Er82e, Er90, Er97c]:

Let p(z) = ∏ᵢ (z - zᵢ) be a polynomial of degree n ≥ 1 with all roots zᵢ
in the closed unit disk (|zᵢ| ≤ 1). Then the 2D Lebesgue measure (area) of
the lemniscate interior {z ∈ ℂ : |p(z)| < 1} satisfies

  |{z : |p(z)| < 1}| ≫ n^{-O(1)}.

That is, there exist universal constants κ > 0 and δ > 0 such that for all n ≥ 1
and all such polynomials, the area is at least δ · n^{-κ}.

The lower bound ≫ n^{-4} follows from a result of Pommerenke [Po61].
The stronger lower bound ≫ (log n)^{-1} was proved by Krishnapur, Lundberg,
and Ramachandran [KLR25], which in particular settles this conjecture.

Pólya [Po28] showed the area is always at most π, with equality only when all
roots are equal.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_116 :
    ∃ (κ δ : ℝ), 0 < δ ∧ 0 < κ ∧
    ∀ (n : ℕ), 1 ≤ n →
    ∀ (roots : Fin n → ℂ), (∀ i, Complex.abs (roots i) ≤ 1) →
    ENNReal.ofReal (δ * (n : ℝ) ^ (-κ)) ≤
      area (lemniscateInterior (∏ i : Fin n, (X - C (roots i)))) :=
  sorry

1→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Coloring
     3→import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     4→import Mathlib.Data.Fintype.Card
     5→import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Card
     6→import Mathlib.Data.Set.Card
     7→
     8→open SimpleGraph
     9→
    10→/-- An injective graph homomorphism from H to F; witnesses that F contains a
    11→    subgraph isomorphic to H. -/
    12→def containsSubgraph {V U : Type*} (F : SimpleGraph V) (H : SimpleGraph U) : Prop :=
    13→  ∃ f : U → V, Function.Injective f ∧ ∀ u v : U, H.Adj u v → F.Adj (f u) (f v)
    14→
    15→/-- The Turán number ex(n; H): the maximum number of edges in a simple graph on n
    16→    vertices that contains no copy of H as a subgraph. -/
    17→noncomputable def turanNumber {U : Type*} (H : SimpleGraph U) (n : ℕ) : ℕ :=
    18→  sSup {m : ℕ | ∃ (V : Type) [Fintype V] (F : SimpleGraph V) [DecidableRel F.Adj],
    19→    Fintype.card V = n ∧ ¬containsSubgraph F H ∧ F.edgeFinset.card = m}
    20→
    21→/-- A graph G is 2-degenerate if every non-empty finite set of vertices contains
    22→    a vertex with at most 2 neighbors within that set.  Equivalently, G has no
    23→    induced subgraph with minimum degree at least 3. -/
    24→def IsTwoDegenerateGraph {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) : Prop :=
    25→  ∀ (S : Set V), S.Finite → S.Nonempty →
    26→    ∃ v ∈ S, (G.neighborSet v ∩ S).ncard ≤ 2
    27→
    28→/--
    29→Erdős-Simonovits Conjecture (Problem #113) [ErSi84]:
    30→For a bipartite graph G on a finite vertex set, the Turán number satisfies
    31→
    32→  ex(n; G) ≪ n^{3/2}
    33→
    34→if and only if G is 2-degenerate (i.e., G has no induced subgraph with minimum
    35→degree at least 3).
    36→
    37→Here ex(n; G) ≪ n^{3/2} means there exists a constant C > 0 such that
    38→ex(n; G) ≤ C · n^{3/2} for all n.
    39→
    40→DISPROVED by Janzer [Ja23b]: for any ε > 0, there exists a 3-regular bipartite
    41→graph H such that ex(n; H) ≪ n^{4/3 + ε}. Since a 3-regular graph is not
    42→2-degenerate but its Turán number is still o(n^{3/2}), the "only if" direction
    43→(ex(n; G) ≪ n^{3/2} → G is 2-degenerate) fails.
    44→-/
    45→theorem erdos_problem_113 :
    46→    ∀ (U : Type*) (G : SimpleGraph U) [Fintype U] [DecidableRel G.Adj],
    47→      Nonempty (G.Coloring (Fin 2)) →
    48→      (IsTwoDegenerateGraph G ↔
    49→        ∃ C : ℝ, 0 < C ∧ ∀ n : ℕ,
    50→          (turanNumber G n : ℝ) ≤ C * (n : ℝ) ^ (3 / 2 : ℝ)) :=
    51→  sorry
    52→

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

file.content:
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Coloring
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Fintype.Card
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Card
import Mathlib.Data.Set.Card

open SimpleGraph

/-- An injective graph homomorphism from H to F; witnesses that F contains a
    subgraph isomorphic to H. -/
def containsSubgraph {V U : Type*} (F : SimpleGraph V) (H : SimpleGraph U) : Prop :=
  ∃ f : U → V, Function.Injective f ∧ ∀ u v : U, H.Adj u v → F.Adj (f u) (f v)

/-- The Turán number ex(n; H): the maximum number of edges in a simple graph on n
    vertices that contains no copy of H as a subgraph. -/
noncomputable def turanNumber {U : Type*} (H : SimpleGraph U) (n : ℕ) : ℕ :=
  sSup {m : ℕ | ∃ (V : Type) [Fintype V] (F : SimpleGraph V) [DecidableRel F.Adj],
    Fintype.card V = n ∧ ¬containsSubgraph F H ∧ F.edgeFinset.card = m}

/-- A graph G is 2-degenerate if every non-empty finite set of vertices contains
    a vertex with at most 2 neighbors within that set.  Equivalently, G has no
    induced subgraph with minimum degree at least 3. -/
def IsTwoDegenerateGraph {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) : Prop :=
  ∀ (S : Set V), S.Finite → S.Nonempty →
    ∃ v ∈ S, (G.neighborSet v ∩ S).ncard ≤ 2

/--
Erdős-Simonovits Conjecture (Problem #113) [ErSi84]:
For a bipartite graph G on a finite vertex set, the Turán number satisfies

  ex(n; G) ≪ n^{3/2}

if and only if G is 2-degenerate (i.e., G has no induced subgraph with minimum
degree at least 3).

Here ex(n; G) ≪ n^{3/2} means there exists a constant C > 0 such that
ex(n; G) ≤ C · n^{3/2} for all n.

DISPROVED by Janzer [Ja23b]: for any ε > 0, there exists a 3-regular bipartite
graph H such that ex(n; H) ≪ n^{4/3 + ε}. Since a 3-regular graph is not
2-degenerate but its Turán number is still o(n^{3/2}), the "only if" direction
(ex(n; G) ≪ n^{3/2} → G is 2-degenerate) fails.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_113 :
    ∀ (U : Type*) (G : SimpleGraph U) [Fintype U] [DecidableRel G.Adj],
      Nonempty (G.Coloring (Fin 2)) →
      (IsTwoDegenerateGraph G ↔
        ∃ C : ℝ, 0 < C ∧ ∀ n : ℕ,
          (turanNumber G n : ℝ) ≤ C * (n : ℝ) ^ (3 / 2 : ℝ)) :=
  sorry

content.thinking: Let me also look at a few more examples to understand the patterns, especially ones that involve group theory.

content.content:
1→import Mathlib.Data.Complex.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Algebra.Polynomial.Basic
     3→import Mathlib.RingTheory.Polynomial.Monic
     4→import Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Measure.Hausdorff
     5→
     6→open Polynomial MeasureTheory
     7→
     8→/-- The unit level curve of a complex polynomial p: the set of z ∈ ℂ with |p(z)| = 1. -/
     9→def levelCurveUnit (p : Polynomial ℂ) : Set ℂ :=
    10→  {z : ℂ | Complex.abs (p.eval z) = 1}
    11→
    12→/-- The arc length of a subset of ℂ, given by the 1-dimensional Hausdorff measure. -/
    13→noncomputable def arcLength (S : Set ℂ) : ℝ≥0∞ :=
    14→  Measure.hausdorffMeasure 1 S
    15→
    16→/--
    17→Erdős-Herzog-Piranian Conjecture (Problem #114) [EHP58]:
    18→If p(z) ∈ ℂ[z] is a monic polynomial of degree n ≥ 1, then the length of the
    19→curve {z ∈ ℂ : |p(z)| = 1} is maximized when p(z) = z^n - 1.
    20→
    21→That is, for every monic polynomial p of degree n,
    22→  length({z : |p(z)| = 1}) ≤ length({z : |z^n - 1| = 1}).
    23→
    24→Known partial results:
    25→- The curve for p(z) = z^n - 1 has length 2n + O(1), so the conjecture implies
    26→  the maximal length f(n) satisfies f(n) = 2n + O(1).
    27→- Dolzhenko (1961): f(n) ≤ 4πn.
    28→- Borwein (1995): f(n) ≪ n.
    29→- Eremenko–Hayman (1999): f(n) ≤ 9.173n; full conjecture holds for n = 2.
    30→- Danchenko (2007): f(n) ≤ 2πn.
    31→- Fryntov–Nazarov (2008): f(n) ≤ 2n + O(n^{7/8}); z^n - 1 is a local maximiser.
    32→- Tao (2025): z^n - 1 is the unique maximiser (up to rotation) for all large n.
    33→-/
    34→theorem erdos_problem_114 :
    35→    ∀ n : ℕ, 1 ≤ n →
    36→    ∀ p : Polynomial ℂ, p.Monic → p.natDegree = n →
    37→      arcLength (levelCurveUnit p) ≤
    38→      arcLength (levelCurveUnit ((X : Polynomial ℂ) ^ n - 1)) :=
    39→  sorry
    40→

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

file.content:
import Mathlib.Data.Complex.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.Polynomial.Basic
import Mathlib.RingTheory.Polynomial.Monic
import Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Measure.Hausdorff

open Polynomial MeasureTheory

/-- The unit level curve of a complex polynomial p: the set of z ∈ ℂ with |p(z)| = 1. -/
def levelCurveUnit (p : Polynomial ℂ) : Set ℂ :=
  {z : ℂ | Complex.abs (p.eval z) = 1}

/-- The arc length of a subset of ℂ, given by the 1-dimensional Hausdorff measure. -/
noncomputable def arcLength (S : Set ℂ) : ℝ≥0∞ :=
  Measure.hausdorffMeasure 1 S

/--
Erdős-Herzog-Piranian Conjecture (Problem #114) [EHP58]:
If p(z) ∈ ℂ[z] is a monic polynomial of degree n ≥ 1, then the length of the
curve {z ∈ ℂ : |p(z)| = 1} is maximized when p(z) = z^n - 1.

That is, for every monic polynomial p of degree n,
  length({z : |p(z)| = 1}) ≤ length({z : |z^n - 1| = 1}).

Known partial results:
- The curve for p(z) = z^n - 1 has length 2n + O(1), so the conjecture implies
  the maximal length f(n) satisfies f(n) = 2n + O(1).
- Dolzhenko (1961): f(n) ≤ 4πn.
- Borwein (1995): f(n) ≪ n.
- Eremenko–Hayman (1999): f(n) ≤ 9.173n; full conjecture holds for n = 2.
- Danchenko (2007): f(n) ≤ 2πn.
- Fryntov–Nazarov (2008): f(n) ≤ 2n + O(n^{7/8}); z^n - 1 is a local maximiser.
- Tao (2025): z^n - 1 is the unique maximiser (up to rotation) for all large n.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_114 :
    ∀ n : ℕ, 1 ≤ n →
    ∀ p : Polynomial ℂ, p.Monic → p.natDegree = n →
      arcLength (levelCurveUnit p) ≤
      arcLength (levelCurveUnit ((X : Polynomial ℂ) ^ n - 1)) :=
  sorry

content.content:
1→import Mathlib.Data.Complex.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Algebra.Polynomial.Basic
     3→import Mathlib.Algebra.Polynomial.Derivative
     4→import Mathlib.Topology.Connected.Basic
     5→
     6→open Polynomial
     7→
     8→/-- The lemniscate of a complex polynomial p: the sublevel set {z ∈ ℂ : |p(z)| ≤ 1}. -/
     9→def lemniscate (p : Polynomial ℂ) : Set ℂ :=
    10→  {z : ℂ | Complex.abs (p.eval z) ≤ 1}
    11→
    12→/--
    13→Erdős Conjecture (Problem #115) [Er61, Er90], proved by Eremenko–Lempert [ErLe94]:
    14→
    15→If p(z) is a polynomial of degree n such that {z ∈ ℂ : |p(z)| ≤ 1} is connected,
    16→then
    17→  max { |p'(z)| : z ∈ ℂ, |p(z)| ≤ 1 } ≤ (1/2 + o(1)) n².
    18→
    19→That is, for every ε > 0 there exists N such that for all n ≥ N, every polynomial
    20→p of degree n whose lemniscate is connected satisfies |p'(z)| ≤ (1/2 + ε) n² for
    21→all z in the lemniscate.
    22→
    23→The Chebyshev polynomials show that the constant 1/2 is sharp. Erdős originally
    24→conjectured the bound n²/2 exactly (without the o(1)), but Szabados observed that
    25→the stronger form fails. Pommerenke [Po59a] proved the weaker bound (e/2) n².
    26→-/
    27→theorem erdos_problem_115 :
    28→    ∀ ε : ℝ, 0 < ε →
    29→    ∃ N : ℕ, ∀ n : ℕ, N ≤ n →
    30→    ∀ p : Polynomial ℂ, p.natDegree = n →
    31→      IsConnected (lemniscate p) →
    32→      ∀ z : ℂ, z ∈ lemniscate p →
    33→        Complex.abs ((derivative p).eval z) ≤ (1 / 2 + ε) * (n : ℝ) ^ 2 :=
    34→  sorry
    35→

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

file.content:
import Mathlib.Data.Complex.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.Polynomial.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.Polynomial.Derivative
import Mathlib.Topology.Connected.Basic

open Polynomial

/-- The lemniscate of a complex polynomial p: the sublevel set {z ∈ ℂ : |p(z)| ≤ 1}. -/
def lemniscate (p : Polynomial ℂ) : Set ℂ :=
  {z : ℂ | Complex.abs (p.eval z) ≤ 1}

/--
Erdős Conjecture (Problem #115) [Er61, Er90], proved by Eremenko–Lempert [ErLe94]:

If p(z) is a polynomial of degree n such that {z ∈ ℂ : |p(z)| ≤ 1} is connected,
then
  max { |p'(z)| : z ∈ ℂ, |p(z)| ≤ 1 } ≤ (1/2 + o(1)) n².

That is, for every ε > 0 there exists N such that for all n ≥ N, every polynomial
p of degree n whose lemniscate is connected satisfies |p'(z)| ≤ (1/2 + ε) n² for
all z in the lemniscate.

The Chebyshev polynomials show that the constant 1/2 is sharp. Erdős originally
conjectured the bound n²/2 exactly (without the o(1)), but Szabados observed that
the stronger form fails. Pommerenke [Po59a] proved the weaker bound (e/2) n².
-/
theorem erdos_problem_115 :
    ∀ ε : ℝ, 0 < ε →
    ∃ N : ℕ, ∀ n : ℕ, N ≤ n →
    ∀ p : Polynomial ℂ, p.natDegree = n →
      IsConnected (lemniscate p) →
      ∀ z : ℂ, z ∈ lemniscate p →
        Complex.abs ((derivative p).eval z) ≤ (1 / 2 + ε) * (n : ℝ) ^ 2 :=
  sorry

content.thinking:
Now I have a good understanding of the patterns used. Let me understand the conjecture in 117.html:

The problem defines h(n) as the minimal value such that any group G with the property that any subset of >n elements contains some x≠y such that xy=yx (i.e., any subset of size > n has two distinct commuting elements) can be covered by at most h(n) many Abelian subgroups.

The task asks to "estimate h(n) as well as possible."

Pyber proved there exist constants c₂ > c₁ > 1 such that c₁⶯ < h(n) < c₂⶯. The lower bound was known to Isaacs.


So I need to formalize the key definitions: a group where any n+1 elements contain a commuting pair, what it means to cover a group by Abelian subgroups, and then h(n) as the minimal covering number for all such groups. The conjecture is Pyber's exponential bounds on h(n). Now I'm formalizing the definitions: a group has the n-commutative property if any subset larger than n contains commuting elements, and h(n) is the minimum number of Abelian subgroups needed to cover any such group. Pyber's theorem establishes that h(n) grows exponentially with specific constants bounding it from above and below, which is the main known result for this estimation problem.

content.text:
## Summary

I found **6 Lean files** in `/home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/` that import or use group theory from Mathlib. The key observation is that all of these files import `Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset` (or the `.Basic` variant), which is a group theory module that provides operations for big operators over finite sets.

Here are the 3 files I read in full:

### 1. /home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/106.lean
**Content**: Defines the Erdős Problem #106 about packing squares inside a unit square. It imports `Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset` to support the summation of side lengths using big operators. The theorem attempts to formalize the conjecture that f(k² + 1) = k.

**Group Theory Usage**: Uses `BigOperators` from group theory to compute sums of side lengths in square configurations.

### 2. /home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/22.lean
**Content**: Formulates the Erdős-Bollobás conjecture on Ramsey-Turán numbers. It imports `Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic` and uses it with graph theory structures to work with edge counts and independent sets.

**Group Theory Usage**: Uses `BigOperators` and `Finset` operations from group theory for computing cardinalities of edge sets and checking properties about cliques.

### 3. /home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/18.lean
**Content**: Formalizes Erdős Problem #18 about practical numbers and the function h(m). It imports `Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic` to support summations of divisors and complex set operations.

**Group Theory Usage**: Uses `BigOperators` for summing distinct divisors of numbers in the practical number definition.

All 6 files that use group theory concepts are:
- /home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/1.lean
- /home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/10.lean
- /home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/12.lean
- /home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/18.lean
- /home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/22.lean
- /home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/106.lean

These files use the algebraic group operations primarily for working with big operators (sums and products) over finite sets, rather than explicit group structures like `Group`, `CommGroup`, or `AbelianGroup`.

content.thinking:
The existing files don't have examples with explicit group theory (Group, Subgroup, etc.). Let me understand what I need to formalize and think through the Lean 4 + Mathlib approach.

The conjecture is about:
1. A function h(n) - the minimal number such that any group G with the property that any subset of >n elements contains two distinct commuting elements can be covered by at most h(n) Abelian subgroups.

2. The task is to "estimate h(n) as well as possible."

3. Known result (Pyber): ∃ c₁, c₂ > 1 such that c₁⶯ < h(n) < c₂⶯.
   
Now I need to set up the formal definitions: the n-commuting property (any subset larger than n has two distinct commuting elements), what it means to cover a group by Abelian subgroups, and h(n) as the minimum such covering size. Then I'll state Pyber's bounds as a known theorem.

For the Lean code, I'll need imports for group theory basics, subgroups, finite sets, and general set operations. Since we're working with finite groups, I need to be careful about how I formalize the n-commuting property in terms of subsets.

Actually, rereading the problem more carefully—G doesn't have to be finite, but the key constraint is that any subset with more than n elements must contain a commuting pair. This means the interesting case is really about subsets of size n+1, where we're guaranteed to find two elements that commute.

So h(n) is asking: what's the minimum number of Abelian subgroups needed to cover any group satisfying this property? I need to formalize what it means for a group to have this n-commutativity property—essentially, every finite subset of size greater than n contains at least one commuting pair.

For the covering part, I'm defining what it means for a group to be covered by k Abelian subgroups: there exist k Abelian subgroups whose union equals the entire group.

Setting up the Lean definitions... Defining the group structure and properties...

I'm setting up the formal definitions for the n-commuting property—a group has this property if any subset larger than size n must contain two distinct elements that commute with each other. Then I'm defining what it means for a group to be covered by k abelian subgroups: there exist k abelian subgroups whose union spans the entire group. The function h(n) computes the minimal number of abelian subgroups needed to cover any group satisfying the n-commuting property. Now I'm starting to formalize Erdős Problem #117... I'm running into a technical issue with how to define h(n) formally—using infimum might not work cleanly if the set is empty or hard to reason about. Let me reconsider the approach: I need to establish that the set of valid covering numbers is non-empty and has a minimum, then state Pyber's bounds on that minimum. infimum satisfies the exponential bounds.

The statement `sInf` returns 0 if the set is empty in Lean's Mathlib, so if h(n) is undefined for some reason, we'd get 0. But mathematically h(n) is always well-defined because the trivial group is Abelian itself.

Actually, let me think more carefully. The `h` function as defined gives the minimal k such that ALL groups with the n-commuting property can be covered by k Abelian subgroups. This k might be infinite (∞) if there are groups requiring arbitrarily many Abelian subgroups.

But Pyber's theorem says h(n) is finite and grows like c^n. So the definition should work.

There's also a universe issue in Lean: when quantifying over all groups with `Type*`, we're including arbitrarily large ones, which might require restricting to smaller groups or using a different formulation. For now I'll keep it simple with `Type*` since it works fine for the formalization.

I need to verify the right predicate for Abelian subgroups in Mathlib—`Subgroup.IsCommutative` captures the commutativity condition we need, and I should check whether to use `CommGroup` or `IsCommutative` for the operation itself. I'm checking whether `Subgroup.IsCommutative` is a typeclass or a proposition in Lean 4 Mathlib, and considering how to cleanly express that all elements in a subgroup commute with each other. I think defining a predicate like `IsAbelian` for subgroups would be the cleanest approach for the formalization. be stated as `∀ a b : G, a ∈ H → b ∈ H → a * b = b * a`. Now I'm setting up the Lean file with the necessary imports and defining the n-commuting property for a group.

Writing Lean code... Defining the covering property and the function h(n) that captures the minimal number of Abelian subgroups needed...

Now I'm formalizing Erdős Problem #117, which asks for bounds on h(n) — Pyber showed it grows exponentially with constants c₁ and c₂ where c₁^n < h(n) < c₂^n, building on earlier work by Isaacs.

I'm running into a universe polymorphism issue with the definition of erdosH — since groups can exist in any universe level, I need to be careful about how I quantify over them in the infimum. Rather than getting bogged down in the technical details of the definition, I'll state the result more abstractly and leave the proof as sorry for now, which is consistent with how similar foundational results are handled elsewhere. Writing Lean definitions... Defining the Erdős function that finds the minimal number of Abelian subgroups needed to cover any group with the n-commuting property, though I'm noticing potential universe level issues with how the definition is structured.

I'm reconsidering the approach to avoid `Finset` complications with decidable equality instances on subgroups. Using a function from `Fin k` to subgroups instead gives me a cleaner way to represent a fixed collection of k Abelian subgroups that cover the group.

Refining the definition...

For the `erdosH` definition, I'm running into universe level issues when trying to quantify over all groups in `Type`. The challenge is that if I use `∀ (G : Type) [Group G]`, I'm only covering groups in universe level 0, but the theorem needs to hold more generally. I need to think about whether to use a universe-polymorphic approach or adjust how the definition captures the minimal number of Abelian subgroups needed across all possible groups.

Since everything will be `sorry`'d anyway, I'll just apply a simple universe restriction and add a comment explaining the limitation. Now I'm setting up the Lean code with the necessary imports and defining the n-commuting property as a predicate on groups, where a group satisfies this property if every subset larger than n contains two commuting elements.

Defining the property... Writing the formal definitions... Finishing the theorem statement and checking the type coercions for the exponential bounds. I need to make sure `rpow` is being used correctly for real number exponentiation when `n` is a natural number, and that the empty set edge case for `sInf` doesn't cause issues since the theorem is still incomplete anyway. I'm checking whether I need `Set.ncard` for cardinality operations, and I think I can skip that import. For the formalization, `Finset G` makes more sense than `Set G` since we're dealing with finite subsets of specific size. Now I need to verify the condition in `HasNCommutingProperty` matches the problem statement—any subset with more than n elements should contain at least two distinct elements that commute. Now I'm settling on Pyber's bounds as the formal statement since that represents the known result for this estimation problem. Before finalizing, I should verify that the type signature actually works in Lean 4—specifically, that `sInf` over a set of natural numbers with the implicit `Group` instance will parse correctly, which it should.

content.text:
Now I have enough context to write the formalization. Let me understand the conjecture:

- `h(n)` = minimal k such that any group G where every subset of size > n has two distinct commuting elements, can be covered by ≤ k Abelian subgroups
- Pyber proved ∃ c₂ > c₁ > 1 such that c₁ⁿ < h(n) < c₂ⁿ
- The open question is to determine h(n) as precisely as possible

input.content:
import Mathlib.GroupTheory.Subgroup.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.Real

/-- A group G satisfies the n-commuting property if every finite subset of size
    greater than n contains two distinct elements x ≠ y with xy = yx. -/
def HasNCommutingProperty (n : ℕ) (G : Type*) [Group G] : Prop :=
  ∀ (S : Finset G), n < S.card →
    ∃ x ∈ S, ∃ y ∈ S, x ≠ y ∧ x * y = y * x

/-- A group G can be covered by at most k Abelian subgroups: there exist k subgroups
    H₀, …, Hₖ₋₁ (possibly with repetition), each of which is abelian, whose union
    is all of G. -/
def CoveredByAbelianSubgroups (k : ℕ) (G : Type*) [Group G] : Prop :=
  ∃ (H : Fin k → Subgroup G),
    (∀ i, ∀ a b : G, a ∈ H i → b ∈ H i → a * b = b * a) ∧
    ∀ g : G, ∃ i, g ∈ H i

/-- h(n) is the least k such that every group (in Type, i.e. the small universe)
    satisfying the n-commuting property can be covered by at most k Abelian
    subgroups. -/
noncomputable def erdosH (n : ℕ) : ℕ :=
  sInf {k : ℕ | ∀ (G : Type) [Group G],
    HasNCommutingProperty n G → CoveredByAbelianSubgroups k G}

/--
Erdős Problem #117 [Er90, Er97f, Va99]:

Let h(n) be minimal such that any group G satisfying the property that every
subset of more than n elements contains distinct commuting elements x ≠ y
(xy = yx) can be covered by at most h(n) Abelian subgroups.

Estimate h(n) as well as possible.

Pyber [Py87] proved there exist constants c₂ > c₁ > 1 such that
  c₁^n < h(n) < c₂^n.
The lower bound c₁^n < h(n) was already known to Isaacs [Er97f].
The precise exponential growth rate of h(n) remains open.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_117 :
    ∃ c₁ c₂ : ℝ, 1 < c₁ ∧ c₁ < c₂ ∧
    ∀ n : ℕ, 1 ≤ n →
      c₁ ^ n < (erdosH n : ℝ) ∧ (erdosH n : ℝ) < c₂ ^ n :=
  sorry

content.content: File created successfully at: /home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/117.lean

import Mathlib.GroupTheory.Subgroup.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.Real

/-- A group G satisfies the n-commuting property if every finite subset of size
    greater than n contains two distinct elements x ≠ y with xy = yx. -/
def HasNCommutingProperty (n : ℕ) (G : Type*) [Group G] : Prop :=
  ∀ (S : Finset G), n < S.card →
    ∃ x ∈ S, ∃ y ∈ S, x ≠ y ∧ x * y = y * x

/-- A group G can be covered by at most k Abelian subgroups: there exist k subgroups
    H₀, …, Hₖ₋₁ (possibly with repetition), each of which is abelian, whose union
    is all of G. -/
def CoveredByAbelianSubgroups (k : ℕ) (G : Type*) [Group G] : Prop :=
  ∃ (H : Fin k → Subgroup G),
    (∀ i, ∀ a b : G, a ∈ H i → b ∈ H i → a * b = b * a) ∧
    ∀ g : G, ∃ i, g ∈ H i

/-- h(n) is the least k such that every group (in Type, i.e. the small universe)
    satisfying the n-commuting property can be covered by at most k Abelian
    subgroups. -/
noncomputable def erdosH (n : ℕ) : ℕ :=
  sInf {k : ℕ | ∀ (G : Type) [Group G],
    HasNCommutingProperty n G → CoveredByAbelianSubgroups k G}

/--
Erdős Problem #117 [Er90, Er97f, Va99]:

Let h(n) be minimal such that any group G satisfying the property that every
subset of more than n elements contains distinct commuting elements x ≠ y
(xy = yx) can be covered by at most h(n) Abelian subgroups.

Estimate h(n) as well as possible.

Pyber [Py87] proved there exist constants c₂ > c₁ > 1 such that
  c₁^n < h(n) < c₂^n.
The lower bound c₁^n < h(n) was already known to Isaacs [Er97f].
The precise exponential growth rate of h(n) remains open.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_117 :
    ∃ c₁ c₂ : ℝ, 1 < c₁ ∧ c₁ < c₂ ∧
    ∀ n : ℕ, 1 ≤ n →
      c₁ ^ n < (erdosH n : ℝ) ∧ (erdosH n : ℝ) < c₂ ^ n :=

import Mathlib.GroupTheory.Subgroup.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.Real

/-- A group G satisfies the n-commuting property if every finite subset of size
    greater than n contains two distinct elements x ≠ y with xy = yx. -/
def HasNCommutingProperty (n : ℕ) (G : Type*) [Group G] : Prop :=
  ∀ (S : Finset G), n < S.card →
    ∃ x ∈ S, ∃ y ∈ S, x ≠ y ∧ x * y = y * x

/-- A group G can be covered by at most k Abelian subgroups: there exist k subgroups
    H₀, …, Hₖ₋₁ (possibly with repetition), each of which is abelian, whose union
    is all of G. -/
def CoveredByAbelianSubgroups (k : ℕ) (G : Type*) [Group G] : Prop :=
  ∃ (H : Fin k → Subgroup G),
    (∀ i, ∀ a b : G, a ∈ H i → b ∈ H i → a * b = b * a) ∧
    ∀ g : G, ∃ i, g ∈ H i

/-- h(n) is the least k such that every group (in Type, i.e. the small universe)
    satisfying the n-commuting property can be covered by at most k Abelian
    subgroups. -/
noncomputable def erdosH (n : ℕ) : ℕ :=
  sInf {k : ℕ | ∀ (G : Type) [Group G],
    HasNCommutingProperty n G → CoveredByAbelianSubgroups k G}

/--
Erdős Problem #117 [Er90, Er97f, Va99]:

Let h(n) be minimal such that any group G satisfying the property that every
subset of more than n elements contains distinct commuting elements x ≠ y
(xy = yx) can be covered by at most h(n) Abelian subgroups.

Estimate h(n) as well as possible.

Pyber [Py87] proved there exist constants c₂ > c₁ > 1 such that
  c₁^n < h(n) < c₂^n.
The lower bound c₁^n < h(n) was already known to Isaacs [Er97f].
The precise exponential growth rate of h(n) remains open.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_117 :
    ∃ c₁ c₂ : ℝ, 1 < c₁ ∧ c₁ < c₂ ∧
    ∀ n : ℕ, 1 ≤ n →
      c₁ ^ n < (erdosH n : ℝ) ∧ (erdosH n : ℝ) < c₂ ^ n :=
  sorry

file.content:
import Mathlib.Algebra.Group.Subgroup.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.Real

/-- A group G satisfies the n-commuting property if every finite subset of size
    greater than n contains two distinct elements x ≠ y with xy = yx. -/
def HasNCommutingProperty (n : ℕ) (G : Type*) [Group G] : Prop :=
  ∀ (S : Finset G), n < S.card →
    ∃ x ∈ S, ∃ y ∈ S, x ≠ y ∧ x * y = y * x

/-- A group G can be covered by at most k Abelian subgroups: there exist k subgroups
    H₀, …, Hₖ₋₁ (possibly with repetition), each of which is abelian, whose union
    is all of G. -/
def CoveredByAbelianSubgroups (k : ℕ) (G : Type*) [Group G] : Prop :=
  ∃ (H : Fin k → Subgroup G),
    (∀ i, ∀ a b : G, a ∈ H i → b ∈ H i → a * b = b * a) ∧
    ∀ g : G, ∃ i, g ∈ H i

/-- h(n) is the least k such that every group (in Type, i.e. the small universe)
    satisfying the n-commuting property can be covered by at most k Abelian
    subgroups. -/
noncomputable def erdosH (n : ℕ) : ℕ :=
  sInf {k : ℕ | ∀ (G : Type) [Group G],
    HasNCommutingProperty n G → CoveredByAbelianSubgroups k G}

/--
Erdős Problem #117 [Er90, Er97f, Va99]:

Let h(n) be minimal such that any group G satisfying the property that every
subset of more than n elements contains distinct commuting elements x ≠ y
(xy = yx) can be covered by at most h(n) Abelian subgroups.

Estimate h(n) as well as possible.

Pyber [Py87] proved there exist constants c₂ > c₁ > 1 such that
  c₁^n < h(n) < c₂^n.
The lower bound c₁^n < h(n) was already known to Isaacs [Er97f].
The precise exponential growth rate of h(n) remains open.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_117 :
    ∃ c₁ c₂ : ℝ, 1 < c₁ ∧ c₁ < c₂ ∧
    ∀ n : ℕ, 1 ≤ n →
      c₁ ^ n < (erdosH n : ℝ) ∧ (erdosH n : ℝ) < c₂ ^ n :=
  sorry

content.text:
The file builds cleanly. Here's a summary of the formalization:

**`HasNCommutingProperty n G`** — the group-theoretic condition: every finite subset of size > n contains distinct x ≠ y with xy = yx.

**`CoveredByAbelianSubgroups k G`** — G is covered by k (possibly repeated) abelian subgroups via an indexed family `Fin k → Subgroup G`, each of which is commutative, and every group element belongs to at least one.

**`erdosH n`** — defined as `sInf` of all k that work universally (over `Type`, the small universe), matching the mathematical definition of the minimal such k.

**`erdos_problem_117`** — states Pyber's exponential bounds: ∃ c₁ < c₂ both > 1 such that c₁ⁿ < h(n) < c₂ⁿ for all n ≥ 1, which is the best known result toward the estimation problem.
